headline: Trump's UK visit: US Big Tech to invest billions in UK's AI
summary: President Trump is visiting the UK to meet with Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Thursday, accompanied by several Big Tech CEOs. This comes as names like Microsoft (MSFT), Google (GOOG, GOOGL), Nvidia (NVDA), Salesforce (CRM), OpenAI (OPAI.PVT), and GSK (GSK) pledged $42.3 billion worth of artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure investments in the UK as part of the "Tech Prosperity Deal." Yahoo Finance anchor Ramzan Karmali joins Morning Brief with Julie Hyman to discuss the details. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
article_text:
President Trump is visiting the UK to meet with Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Thursday, accompanied by several Big Tech CEOs. This comes as names like Microsoft (MSFT), Google (GOOG, GOOGL), Nvidia (NVDA), Salesforce (CRM), OpenAI (OPAI.PVT), and GSK (GSK) pledged $42.3 billion worth of artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure investments in the UK as part of the "Tech Prosperity Deal."
Yahoo Finance anchor Ramzan Karmali joins Morning Brief with Julie Hyman to discuss the details.
To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
And finally, let's talk about President Trump's visit to the UK. He's been greeted with a lot of fanfare, not just from officials there, you know, royalty, etc., but from companies that are also uh inking partnerships there, Ramzan.
That's right. There's a lot of pageantry, but it's interesting to note that President Trump isn't in London, he's in Windsor. There have been protests as well. But he has been accompanied by uh quite a few of the, you know, leading names in technology, US leading names. Among them, uh Jensen Huang, from Nvidia's Jensen Huang and also Microsoft's Satya Nadela are all are with him as well. And what they've the two countries have agreed is a big, what they called a tech prosperity deal. And it's estimated to be worth around 42 billion dollars. And some of the investments that have been promised include Microsoft saying it'll spend around 30 billion dollars expanding cloud and AI infrastructure in the UK. Google's promised almost 7 billion dollars in spending on a new data center and AI research. Nvidia said it would deploy 120,000 advanced chips across the country. So, a lot of US investment uh in the UK, uh also Salesforce has said they're going to invest, Core Weave as well. So, that's good for the UK, but what about the US? Well, on the flip side, the British pharmaceutical firm GSK said it's going to invest 30 billion dollars in US research and development and supply chain infrastructure over the next five years. Now, remember, Pharma is a bit of a hot topic because of President Trump's threat to potentially somewhere down the line to hit hit uh the these drug companies with 200% tariffs. Well, a lot of companies are already making that move to invest in the UK to avoid that. So, that's quite an interesting take. Also an interesting thing on the tech front, the investment in um the UK could be quite significant because just across the water, across the channel, uh in Europe, there's a bit of a an uneasy relationship with US tech firms and these and uh the European regulators there. And President Trump has often criticized you the EU uh in terms of their how how they hit US tech firms. So maybe going to the UK is is one way of showing, well, actually, we don't need you, we can go to the UK and we can be as prosperous there. Uh also, the UK is desperate as well for this investment. GDP growth in the three months up to July was just 0.2% in the UK. So the economy not really firing on on all cylinders. So this investment will be uh very much welcome here in the UK.

headline: Meet Quantum Computing's Potential Monster Stocks of the Next Decade (Hint: Not IonQ)
summary: Quantum computing is emerging as an interesting new frontier in the artificial intelligence (AI) landscape.
article_text:
Over the past few years, much of the excitement around artificial intelligence (AI) has centered on how advanced chipsets known as graphics processing units (GPUs) are enabling developers to build and train large language models (LLMs). But looking ahead, AI use cases are expected to grow even more complex and reach broader end markets.
One of the more intriguing frontiers is quantum computing -- an emerging technology with the potential to transform mission-critical industries such as energy and financial services. Analysts from McKinsey & Company are projecting that quantum applications could unlock trillions in economic value in the long run.
Naturally, investors are curious: Which of today's AI titans are positioning themselves to lead the quantum era? In my eyes, two companies stick out as particularly well positioned to dominate the next wave of the AI narrative.
Nvidia: Building the hardware + software quantum stack
It wasn't long ago that Nvidia (NVDA -0.17%) was perceived as a niche hardware designer that primarily catered to online gamers. That narrow view dramatically underestimated the foresight of Nvidia's visionary CEO, Jensen Huang. Nearly two decades ago, Huang recognized that GPUs had the potential to impact industries far beyond gaming.
Today, these same chipsets serve as the foundation for deploying generative AI models like ChatGPT. But what truly sets Nvidia apart from the competition is its comprehensive ecosystem that extends beyond hardware expertise.
At the core is CUDA, Nvidia's software architecture that layers on top of its GPUs. This end-to-end integration has helped Nvidia build a powerful lock-in effect with developers -- essentially turning the company into a full-spectrum backbone for building AI systems.
While these dynamics have helped Nvidia form a technological moat, the company is quietly working to extend its dominance even further. CUDA is now becoming a bridge connecting conventional (classical) GPU programming with quantum workloads, helping position Nvidia at the center of emerging frontiers in the AI landscape.
The combination of hardware and software stack has helped Nvidia create a platform with durable competitive advantages. This flywheel effect not only reinforces its leadership in the AI industry but also positions the company to benefit from new tailwinds such as quantum computing.
Alphabet: Purpose-built for the quantum era
When most investors think of Alphabet, their minds go straight to Google search or YouTube. Advertising still fuels the majority of Alphabet's cash flow, but beneath the surface, the company has quietly built one of the most advanced AI ecosystems on the market. And a particularly important -- albeit overlooked -- pillar of that strategy is quantum computing.
On the hardware side, Alphabet developed a quantum processor called Willow. In benchmark tests, Willow solved an equation in minutes that would take today's most powerful supercomputers an estimated 10 septillion years to complete.
On the research side, one of Alphabet's lesser-known subsidiaries is a research lab called DeepMind. The advantage of DeepMind is that Alphabet can quickly and constantly test and refine new chip architectures and AI applications -- making them readily available for the company's enterprise and consumer product suites.
Lastly, on the infrastructure side are Alphabet's tensor processing units (TPUs) and its open-source software framework, Cirq. This combination has the potential to usher in a new wave of AI workloads into Alphabet's budding cloud computing network, Google Cloud Platform (GCP). In the long run, this could prove to be an interesting differentiator for GCP over larger incumbents like Microsoft Azure or Amazon Web Services (AWS).
The key takeaway is that Alphabet's ambitions in quantum computing are far from a theoretical exercise. By deliberately building a vertically integrated stack across chips, research, software, and infrastructure, Alphabet underscores its AI-first identity well beyond search and advertising.
This breadth not only augments the core business, but more importantly, it provides some needed optionality -- ultimately ensuring that Alphabet remains nimble and adaptive in a fast-changing technology landscape.

headline: ADI's Industrial Segment Improves: What's Driving the Growth?
summary: Analog Devices' Industrial segment surges 23% with growth in automation, aerospace, and AI-driven test equipment demand.
article_text:
Analog Devices’ ADI Industrial segment is experiencing massive growth on the back of demand for its offerings across instrumentation, automation, health care, aerospace and defense and energy management businesses, as mentioned in their recent earnings call. The Industrial segment grew 23% year over year in the third quarter of fiscal 2025.
The industrial segment showed robust growth across all subsectors and geographies, mainly driven by automatic test equipment, benefiting from AI chip infrastructure buildout and record aerospace & defense performance. ADI’s automation business also showed double-digit growth. ADI sees potential to double its automation business by 2030.
In the robotics front, Analog Devices has partnered with Teradyne to advance its footprint in the robotics market. ADI’s positioning and dynamic motion control systems are enabling Teradyne to develop high-performing cobots and autonomous mobile robots for the logistics industry.
ADI is also working with NVIDIA on digital twin simulations and reference designs for humanoid and advanced robotic systems. With all these factors at play, ADI expects its Industrial segment to grow at the fastest pace among all its segments. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for ADI’s fiscal 2025 and 2026 revenues is expected to grow 15% and 17.4%, respectively.
How Competitors Fare Against Analog Devices
Analog Devices competes with Texas Instruments TXN and STMicroelectronics STM in the Industrial segment. Texas Instruments competes with ADI in industrial signal chains, precision sensing, and power management, especially in PLCs, factory automation, and motor control. STMicroelectronics competes in industrial MCUs, motor drivers, sensors, and automation systems.
In the robotics space, STMicroelectronics provides sensors, motor control ICs, and power management for cobots, AMRs, and humanoid robots. In automation, Texas Instruments provides low-power precision analog and sensing for medical imaging, patient monitoring, and diagnostics.
Both STMicroelectronics and Texas Instruments compete with ADI in the aerospace and defence business through their radiation-hardened analog and mixed-signal ICs, secure communications, and avionics systems.
ADI’s Price Performance, Valuation and Estimates
Shares of ADI have gained 14.9% year to date against the Semiconductor - Analog and Mixed industry’s growth of 11.1%.
Image Source: Zacks Investment Research
From a valuation standpoint, ADI trades at a forward price-to-sales ratio of 10.02X, lower than the industry’s average of 7.57X.
Image Source: Zacks Investment Research

headline: China bans Nvidia chip purchases for tech companies, FT reports
summary: China has reportedly banned firms from buying Nvidia (NVDA) products, according to reporting from the Financial Times. Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Allie Canal outlines the details. Check out Yahoo Finance's interview with Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
article_text:
China has reportedly banned firms from buying Nvidia (NVDA) products, according to reporting from the Financial Times. Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Allie Canal outlines the details.
Check out Yahoo Finance's interview with Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang.
To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
I want to turn to another story that we are watching closely, and that is the continuing negotiations between the US and China with Nvidia sort of in the middle as a pawn and all of this. As we talked about, the FT is reporting that China's instructed its companies to not buy Nvidia chips. And I recently had a talk the chance to talk to Nvidia's CEO, Jensen Wong, following its earnings and asked him, you know, how necessary is China even for the business? This is what he said.
Every American technology company, um, for every every American technology company, China is important to them. It's an important market. It's also, as you know, it's just really large. It's the second largest computing market in the world. Um, and um, I I'm I'm just delighted that President Trump uh sees the wisdom of American leadership and and particularly at this time uh where AI is taking off, it's vital that America wins the AI race.
And yet, Ally, you know, the shares, yes, they're down this morning a little more than a percent, but we it doesn't seem as though investors are especially concerned. Um, you know, the shares are still up 30% this year for example.
Right. and China is an important market to Nvidia, but it is not the most important market. There certainly is a lot of demand here in the US as well. But this does mark a significant escalation. Now, regulators have previously targeted Nvidia's H20 chips. Those were those paired back processors meant to uh comply with those US export controls. Now the directive extends to the RTX Pro 6000D. That's Nvidia's newest AI chips, customized for China, a lower-powered version of its flagship processor, meant to comply with those same rules. But the timing is also notable. Just a few days ago, uh China accused Nvidia of violating its anti-monopoly law. This comes as President Trump continues to push policies restricting China's access to US chips. At the same time, China is trying to lessen its dependence on US technologies for these exact reasons. And like you said, shares are down slightly in pre-market trading. We did hear from Nvidia's CEO Jensen Wong responding to this report. He said he was quote disappointed, but understood that China and the US have larger geopolitical issues to work out. He described Nvidia's business in China as a bit of a roller coaster and stressed that the company has guided Wall Street not to factor China into its financial forecast given the policy uncertainty. And that may be why we're seeing a bit more muted reaction in shares, because even without China, guidance wasn't too bad in the latest quarter. So, if this China uh issue is resolved, that could be a further boon for Nvidia down the line here. But like you said, Nvidia once again a pawn in this game between the US, China as these trade negotiations continue. President Trump will be meeting with Xi Jinping on Friday. I'm sure this will be a big talking point.

headline: AI Weekly: OpenAI makes a deal, Oracle makes waves
summary: STORY: From OpenAI getting one step closer to making money, to how Oracle made Wall Street take notice, this is AI Weekly.:: AI Weekly:: MicrosoftMicrosoft and OpenAI have struck a deal to restructure their relationship.Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.:: MicrosoftBut the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.:: OracleOracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.” Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangThe bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangNow the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.
article_text:
STORY: From OpenAI getting one step closer to making money, to how Oracle made Wall Street take notice, this is AI Weekly.
:: AI Weekly
:: Microsoft
Microsoft and OpenAI have struck a deal to restructure their relationship.
Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.
OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.
:: Microsoft
But the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.
Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.
Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.
They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.
And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.
:: Oracle
Oracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.
Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.
GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:
"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.”
Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.
That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.
Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.
And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.
Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.
:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun Wang
The bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.
:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun Wang
Now the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.

headline: Nvidia CEO disappointed over China chip ban report
summary: Nvidia chief executive Jensen Huang on Wednesday said he was disappointed by a report that Beijing has barred major Chinese tech companies from buying his company's world-leading chips, a crucial component in the generative AI revolution.Beijing has responded by expressing national security concerns about Nvidia chips and urging Chinese businesses to rely on local semiconductor suppliers instead.
article_text:
Nvidia chief executive Jensen Huang on Wednesday said he was disappointed by a report that Beijing has barred major Chinese tech companies from buying his company's world-leading chips, a crucial component in the generative AI revolution.
California-based Nvidia's specially designed chips have catapulted the company to become the world's biggest by market capitalisation, with China seen as a crucial market.
But geopolitical tensions between the United States and China have seen Nvidia caught up in relations between the superpowers.
Washington restricts Nvidia from exporting its most advanced products to China and last month confirmed the company would pay the US government 15 percent of revenue from certain AI chip sales in the country.
Beijing has responded by expressing national security concerns about Nvidia chips and urging Chinese businesses to rely on local semiconductor suppliers instead.
In the latest development, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday that China's internet regulator has instructed companies including Alibaba and ByteDance to terminate orders for Nvidia's RTX Pro 6000D chips, state-of-the-art processors made especially for the country.
"We can only be in service of a market if a country wants us to be," Huang said at a press briefing in London, responding to a question about the FT report.
"I'm disappointed with what I see, but they have larger agendas to work out between China and the United States. And I'm patient about it. We'll continue to be supportive of the Chinese government and Chinese companies as they wish."
According to the FT, citing unnamed sources, the Cyberspace Administration of China ordered companies to end all testing and purchase plans for Nvidia's restricted chips.
The ban would follow a decision by Chinese regulators on Monday finding that Nvidia had run afoul of the country's antitrust rules.
Observers believe that Beijing's moves to wean Chinese tech companies off Nvidia's offerings are part of its effort to accelerate domestic production from companies like Huawei.
arp/lth

headline: Dan Niles Says Nvidia (NVDA) Data Center Miss Should Not Be Ignored
summary: We recently published 10 Stock News You Should Pay Attention To. NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) is one of the stocks to watch in September. Dan Niles from Niles Investment Management, in a recent program on CNBC, reiterated his concerns about a potential slowdown in AI demand. This time, Niles highlighted Nvidia’s data center miss in its […]
article_text:
We recently published 10 Stock News You Should Pay Attention To. NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) is one of the stocks to watch in September.
Dan Niles from Niles Investment Management, in a recent program on CNBC, reiterated his concerns about a potential slowdown in AI demand. This time, Niles highlighted Nvidia’s data center miss in its latest quarterly report.
“Over the weekend it came out that OpenAI has sort of pushed up their revenue forecast for 2030 by about $26 billion to $200 billion,” Niles said. “But to get that revenue increase of $26 billion, they’re going to have to burn $85 billion more in cash. So the data points are definitely there, but you know, we’re in this business to make money. So you have to go, all right, well, do the fundamentals matter right now, or is it the fact you’re going to get even more easy money? The 10-year yields going down to 4%. And so this market, much like in 2021, will keep going up right up until it doesn’t. And so I think you have to look at that. And Nvidia missing on data center revenues, and you can say yes the growth was so high and all this, but they missed, so that should give you another data point. And you throw on top of that Dell or Marll or the fact that AVGO got more ASIC revenues because companies want to cut their costs—those all speak to the same narrative, so don’t confuse the actual data with what the stock prices are doing.”
Photo by Kaleidico on Unsplash
Nvidia’s Hopper Infrastructure and now Blackwell form the core of AI infrastructure for LLM training and inference. But Nvidia’s growth is slowing compared to previous quarters amid competition and capex spending limitations from major companies. In the recently reported quarter, Nvidia’s annual revenue growth came in at 56%, compared with nearly 100% YoY growth in the past.
With its strong position in the data center market and rising demand, Nvidia is likely to keep growing, though not at the same pace it has in the past. Increasing competition from major companies like Broadcom is also expected to impact Nvidia’s margins in the long term.
Loomis Sayles Growth Fund stated the following regarding NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) in its second quarter 2025 investor letter:
“NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) is the world leader in artificial intelligence (AI) computing, which enables computers to mimic human-like intelligence for problem solving and decision making capabilities. Founded in 1993 to develop faster and more-realistic graphics for PC-based video games, Nvidia created the first graphics processing unit (GPU), a dedicated semiconductor that employs a proprietary parallel processing architecture to perform superior graphics rendering outside of a computer’s standard central processing unit (CPU). The parallel processing capability of Nvidia’s GPUs, which contrasts with the linear processing requirement of CPUs, can accelerate computing functions performed by standard CPUs by greater than ten times. As a result, Nvidia extended its visual computing expertise beyond its legacy gaming market into innovative new and larger markets, including data centers, autos, and professional visualization. The parallel processing capability facilitates pattern recognition and machine learning functions that have enabled Nvidia to be at the forefront of growth in artificial intelligence applications. As a result, the data center business, which first surpassed the gaming business to become Nvidia’s largest revenue and profit generator in its 2023 fiscal year, grew to represent over 88% of revenue in the company’s most recent fiscal year. The company is also focused on building out its GPU-computing-based ecosystem and is helping to enable breakthroughs in autonomous driving, and virtual reality.

headline: From 'Liability' to 'Dream Come True' - Redditor Who Invested $36,000 in Nvidia 8 Years Ago Sells Entire Position After Reaching $1 Million Profit
summary: Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) has emerged as the biggest beneficiary of the generative AI boom that started with the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022. Since the AI tool's launch, the stock has surged over 900%, rewarding investors who got in early. In July, an investor on Reddit shared how he got in early on Nvidia, turning an initial investment of $36,352 into more than $1 million in profits by patiently holding the stock for eight years. Don't Miss: Would You Have Invested in eBay or Uber Early? The
article_text:
From 'Liability' to 'Dream Come True' - Redditor Who Invested $36,000 in Nvidia 8 Years Ago Sells Entire Position After Reaching $1 Million Profit
Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) has emerged as the biggest beneficiary of the generative AI boom that started with the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022. Since the AI tool's launch, the stock has surged over 900%, rewarding investors who got in early.
In July, an investor on Reddit shared how he got in early on Nvidia, turning an initial investment of $36,352 into more than $1 million in profits by patiently holding the stock for eight years.
Don't Miss:
-
Would You Have Invested in eBay or Uber Early? The Same Backers Are Betting on This Vacation Home Platform
-
They Sold Their Last Real Estate Company for Nearly $1B — Now They're Building the Future of U.S. Industrial Growth
The investor said that he began buying Nvidia shares back in 2017 because he believed the company's graphics processing units would be used for mining cryptocurrencies. Bitcoin hit $20,000 for the first time that year, but soon "collapsed," introducing the Redditor to the volatility of the crypto world, he said. However, he did not sell Nvidia because he believed crypto was in its "early adoption stage."
From Crypto to Electric Vehicles
The Redditor said he kept slowly adding to his Nvidia stake over the next couple of years, and by 2019, he owned about 6,000 shares of the company. In 2019 and 2020, the investor began to feel that Nvidia GPUs were not as closely tied to the crypto industry as once thought. However, there was a new reason for him to keep holding Nvidia in his portfolio.
"The hype around Tesla was growing and crypto mining started moving away from personal computers and I learned GPUs were falling out of favor for more powerful ASIC mining rigs," he said. "So my mentality moved from crypto to electric vehicles."
Trending: ‘Scrolling To UBI' — Deloitte's #1 fastest-growing software company allows users to earn money on their phones. You can invest today for just $0.30/share.
‘Temptation' to Sell
Then came 2023, and the world started to see the impact of generative AI, thanks to the launch of ChatGPT in the previous year. The Redditor said he started seeing "mainstream use cases" for AI because he worked in the photography and videography industry.
The investor said his portfolio started to "skyrocket" because of Nvidia. His position in the chip maker was up 4000% and the "temptation" to sell was growing.
"Once a liability, Nvidia now made up 10%, 20%, and 30% of my entire investment account and retirement funds," he wrote. "There were days when I would log in to see I had made $100,000 that day and a week later it would swing down -$105,000. It was pretty crazy to see a full year's worth of income bouncing around day by day in my account."

OK, first up, we've got General Mills. Now you might be tucking into one of their cereals like Cheerios or Lucky Charms, but they've just reported earnings. And actually, the earnings beat consensus, and adjusted earnings per share came in at 86 cents. The markets were looking for 82 cents, and net sales actually came in at $4.52 billion which was in line with expectations, but that's had very little impact on the share price in pre-market.Down there a little bit there. Now for context, General Mills has been under pressure amid inflation pushing consumers to cheaper products and changing consumption patterns as people seek more healthy products. Pet food has been one bright spot for General Mills, and now we'll see how investors will react to these results which follow aggressive cost cuts and new product launches. One thing that that General Mills did say is that more people are choosing to eat at home.OK, now you need to know that Workday, the enterprise software is up more than 9% in pre-market. The company held an event for analysts yesterday and it announced some new plans, including snapping up the AI startup Sanna. The growth plans got a thumbs up uh from activist investor Elliott Management. OK, next up, a stock you want to watch closely, blockchain lender figure.The stock is up again, more than 3% in pre-market after it jumped 30% yesterday and gave up some gains to close about 8.4% higher, actually it's now up 4% in pre-market. Now, investors are loading their portfolios ahead of the Fed's decision today and figure is attracting optimism after what is widely seen as a successful IPO last week.In which it raised about $790 million. And while we're talking about this company will also bring you a headline about another tech company called Fi. This one is Fi AI which makes humanoid robots and is based in San Francisco. The startup is private, so harder to trade, but the news is that it has reached a $39 billion valuation after it raised over $1 billion in a Series C funding round that involved giant names including Intel Capital, Salesforce, Qualcomm and Nvidia.Well, speaking of Nvidia, we've been watching news today that the stock is coming under even more pressure from China. So let's take a look at some key AI stocks this morning that are moving on US China negotiations. But Nvidia, we're not seeing great giant swings, we can see that the stock is sliding again.Uh, maybe there might be some profit taking there as the FT reports that a Chinese government entity has instructed leading tech companies to stop purchasing and even to cancel existing orders of Nvidia's GPUs. This comes on top of more bad news for Nvidia this week in China, where it faces an antitrust probe.And as Beijing steps up its pressure on on Nvidia amid trade negotiations with the US, China's homegrown chip companies are gaining momentum. Look at Baidu, the Chinese tech giant is up about 16% in Hong Kong and its NASAQ listed shares are up more than 8% in pre-market. That's after its in-house chip making unit.Got an analyst upgrade. Meanwhile, Alibaba continues to gain ground, often dubbed China's Amazon. Alibaba is attracting new momentum with investors as it makes progress on its AI cloud expansion. It's up again more than 5% in Hong Kong today, and remember, this is one of the companies that have been asked to stop using Nvidia chips.

headline: Fed decision, China's Nvidia ban, TikTok deal: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are largely flat as Wall Street awaits the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate decision coming out of its policy meeting later today. Experts anticipate Fed officials to cut rates by 25 basis points for the first time in 2025. article_text:
US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are largely flat as Wall Street awaits the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate decision coming out of its policy meeting later today. Experts anticipate Fed officials to cut rates by 25 basis points for the first time in 2025.
China is banning companies from buying AI chips from major semiconductor manufacturer Nvidia (NVDA), according to Financial Times reports.
Following fresh trade negotiations between the US and China, the latter has agreed to a deal framework for selling TikTok. Hear what Wire China editor Andrew Peaple has to say about US-China trade talks in regards to Nvidia, TikTok, and more.
To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.
Let's get to the three things you need to know today. First up, US stock futures holding steady ahead of the Fed rate decision due at 2 p.m. Eastern time today. The Federal Reserve widely expected to cut interest rates at its meeting amid growing signs of weakness in the labor market. This would mark the first rate cut from the Fed since 2024, and traders are betting on more ahead. All eyes will be on Fed Chair Jay Powell's press conference for clues on the central bank's path forward. Plus, China reportedly banning.Companies from purchasing invidious AI chips. According to the Financial Times, China's internet watchdog has instructed companies to terminate orders for invidious chips. Among the buyer canceling orders, Alibaba, TikTok parent company ByteDance. The decision marks an escalation in US-China trade tensions ahead of a planned call between Trump and Xi this Friday. And during that call, the president will discuss the state of TikTok's US operations. If all goes to plan, the social media's US operation.would be acquired by several companies including Oracle, venture capital firm Andries and Horowitz, and private equity firm Silver Lake. That's according to Bloomberg. TikTok's ban was set to go into effect today, but the deadline has now been extended until December. The deal calls for Oracle to continue providing cloud services for TikTok. Oracle already works with the company to host user data in the US as part of a multi-billion dollar partnership that TikTok has dubbed Project Texas.

headline: New Record Highs on S&P, Nasdaq: Tech Stocks Still Lead
summary: The (AI-based) tech trade joins a pending lower interest rate environment for a market-friendly blend.
article_text:
Monday, September 15, 2025
An opening trading session for what promises to be an eventful week saw new closing highs on both the S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq. In a nutshell, the bull market continues its move forward under the same narrative it’s had for some time: the (AI-based) tech trade joins a pending lower interest rate environment for a market-friendly blend.
The Tech sector is at a record high, as are Financials. While the Dow failed to notch a new record-high close today, it did gain +49 points, +0.11%. The S&P 500 surged over 6600 for the first time, +30 points, +0.47%. The Nasdaq gathered another +207 points, +0.94% to 22,348, and the small-cap Russell 2000 continues to seek out those new closing highs, +0.34% on the session.
TikTok Ownership Coming to U.S. Shores?
Reportedly, the “framework” of a deal over the ownership of Chinese social media giant TikTok has been agreed to by both U.S. and Chinese negotiators today, according to Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. While it remains unclear which assets have been agreed to be sold, to which company or companies, for how much and with what constraints, Bessent says details will be forthcoming this week.
CoreWeave Deal with NVIDIA Sends Shares Up +7%
AI cloud services provider CoreWeave CRWV has announced an agreement with AI chip leader NVIDIA NVDA worth $6.3 billion, which will obligate NVIDIA to buy up remaining data center space at CoreWeave through mid-April 2032. Shares of CRWV gained +7% on this news today, while NVDA stock was flat.
What to Expect from the Stock Market Tomorrow
Tuesday morning brings us a truckload of new economic data, with U.S. Retail Sales, Import/Export Prices, and Industrial Production/Capacity Utilization for August before the opening bell. We’ll also get a look at Business Inventories for July and Homebuilder Confidence for September a little later on that morning.
The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) starts its two-day meeting tomorrow, as it deliberates on monetary policy and decides on interest rate levels the following day. Expectations are for the first of three 25 basis-point (bps) cuts to the Fed funds rate through the end of the calendar year, which would bring down rates initially to 4.00-4.25%. By the December meeting, interest rates are now expected to be 3.50-3.75%.
Also, we may see a last-minute addition to the FOMC at these meetings, as long as the Republican-run Senate continues to do President Trump’s bidding: Stephen Miran, currently the president’s Chair of the Presidential Council of Economic Advisors and likeminded with Trump that interest rates are about 300 bps too high, will likely get a vote early this evening. It is also likely Fed Governor Lisa Cook will stay on the FOMC, despite President Trump attempting to fire her.

headline: With no DOJ breakup, Alphabet becomes a $3 trillion company
summary: Investors continue to reward Alphabet's stock after a judge declined to break up Google earlier this month.
article_text:
Alphabet hit just over $3 trillion dollars in market cap on Monday as investors continue to reward it after a federal judge declined to break the company up.
On Sept. 2, U.S. District Court Judge Amit P. Mehta outlined softer-than-feared remedies for his year-ago ruling that Google maintained an illegal monopoly in search. The DOJ had proposed stronger remedies, including that Alphabet-owned Google be forced to sell Chrome. Tech companies like Perplexity and Ecosia lined up with unsolicited bids. But that possibility has been nixed.
Beyond Google’s cash cow of search, its cloud computing business is also growing rapidly on the strength of its AI offerings. Alphabet now joins Nvidia ($4.3T), Microsoft ($3.8T) and Apple ($3.5T) in the three-t club with Amazon next up but a lap behind ($2.5T).

headline: China Says Nvidia Broke Rules In $7 Billion Mellanox Deal
summary: Regulators cite broken conditions in $7 billion acquisition approval
article_text:
This article first appeared on GuruFocus.
China has decided Nvidia (NVDA) broke antitrust rules tied to its $7 billion purchase of Mellanox Technologies back in 2020, putting fresh strain on U.S.China relations just as trade talks are heating up.
The country's market regulator said a preliminary review found Nvidia failed to live up to certain conditions agreed to when China cleared the deal. Officials didn't spell out what exactly was violated, but the ruling highlights how closely Beijing is watching U.S. tech firms. Nvidia stock slipped about 2% in premarket trading on the news.
Nvidia bought Mellanox, an Israeli company that makes networking gear for data centers and servers, to strengthen its AI and cloud ambitions. Chinese regulators reopened their look at the deal late last year, signaling ongoing concerns about how much control Nvidia wields in the market.
The move lands at a delicate time, raising questions about whether this is strictly about competitionor another shot in the broader U.S.China tech fight.
